content: Prior to SAFETEA, the Transportation Equity Act for the 21st Century (TEA-21) authorized federal highway, highway safety, and transit programs from FY1998-FY2003. After October 1, 2003, short-term extension acts continued funding for federal surface transportation programs. Long-term reauthorizations, like TEA-21, are preferred for better long-term planning and construction needs in the surface transportation community. The passage of SAFETEA was welcomed by the transportation community as it provided long-term reauthorization for highway and transit infrastructure, reducing uncertainty about future funding. Despite delays, SAFETEA was passed as a four-year bill expiring in FY2009, closely linked to federal funding for surface transportation. The passage converted a six-year bill to a four-year bill expiring in FY2009, funded by the highway trust fund through gasoline and diesel fuel taxes.
